The war in Ukraine has been overshadowed by the recent mutiny of the Wagner paramilitary group in Russia. Ukrainian combat medics, who were civilians before the war, are now risking their lives to treat their wounded countrymen while trying to protect themselves from artillery fire and rocket attacks. Despite their fatigue and doubts about when the conflict might end, they are motivated to keep going because they feel their country needs them. They are also driven by a personal struggle to protect their families and their own lives. Before the war, these medics were anesthesiologists, surgeons, nurses and so on at civilian hospitals, but now they are working in a frontline military hospital. Despite the fatigue and risks, they are determined to continue fighting. Meanwhile, Putin is trying to punish those responsible for the rebellion, but it is proving difficult due to their deep ties to the Moscow elite.

  1. The war in Ukraine has been ongoing for over a year, with Russian soldiers killing or wounding thousands of Ukrainian troops each week.
  2. Ukrainian combat medics, who were previously civilian doctors and nurses, are risking their lives to treat their wounded countrymen.
  3. The mood among Ukrainian medics is one of exhaustion, but they are motivated to keep going because they feel their country needs them.
  4. Vladimir Putin is planning to punish those who enabled Yevgeny Prigozhin's rebellion, but the Wagner leader's deep ties to the Moscow elite are making that difficult.
  5. An unlikely obstacle has slowed Ukraine's counteroffensive: flat, open fields.
